1448389919932616704.text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS @SenatorLeahy Thank you to @Tim_Cook for joining me at @SiliconSlopes Summit 2021.

1448389555648966661.text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS @SenatorLeahy Tim Cook: Listening to the reaction here, it might be the best decision I’ll ever make.

1448389536573280259.text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS @SenatorLeahy Mike Lee: There’s something amazing we’ve developed here, over generations, it’s called fry sauce. I highly recommend it. Would you consider serving it in your dining areas?

1448388823256342529.text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS @SenatorLeahy Mike Lee: I can’t live without my iPad. I take it with me everywhere, hearings, meetings. The only way I can read everything I vote on without carrying a truckload of paper, is on my iPad.

1448388581102391296.text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS @SenatorLeahy Tim Cook to Mike Lee: Other than your phone, what would you say is the one piece of technology you can’t live without?

1448388358326165504.text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS @SenatorLeahy Tim Cook: A privacy “back door” would be terrible for our consumers. You can’t make a “back door” for only the good guys. If there’s a door, anyone can find a way in.

1448388107078971396.text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS @SenatorLeahy Tim Cook: I don’t have the ability to come into your house uninvited. I shouldn’t have the ability to get into your data.

1448387747346063372.text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS @SenatorLeahy Tim Cook: We feel a significant responsibility for our customers to make sure they are taken care of with privacy. That’s why we believe in encryption. We don’t have the tools to unlock your phone. The only person with a key to your phone is you.

1448387559395053569.text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS @SenatorLeahy Mike Lee to Tim Cook: Why is this such a priority for Apple and what do you make of the state of privacy protections today? What role does encryption play in efforts to protect user privacy?

1448387241785577474.text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS Mike Lee: We fought a revolution in part because of excessive intrusion into our privacy. Today, our personal details aren’t just in papers. They’re all over in our data. That’s why I worked with @SenatorLeahy to pass the USA Freedom Act which ended mass phone record collection.

1448386524584816649.text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS Tim Cook to Mike Lee: What’s your view on the dangers of unchecked data collection?

1448386090482769925.text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS Mike Lee: There’s always something you can find that interests you. A few weeks ago on a whim, I wanted to learn Morse code, it turns out there’s an app for that. We live in a time and age when you can do what interests you. If you want to learn or do something, you can.

1448385456958287875.text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS Tim Cook to Mike Lee: I’m so impressed by young people today — by their values, their ambition, their sense of purpose. What advice do you have for young people today looking to find their life’s work?

1448385191718830080.text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS Tim Cook: All too often technology gets lumped together with big tech. It’s easy to lump things together, but it’s rarely correct to do so. Just like you don’t want to lump people together, you don’t want to lump businesses together.

1448384817746296835.text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS Tim Cook: Robust tech competition is important. For any functioning market to continue innovating, you need competition. Our competitors make us a better company.

1448384784833695747.text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS Mike Lee to Tim Cook: From your perspective, what’s the value of competition, and how can we make the technology space more competitive?

1448384353692696577.text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS Mike Lee: My Government Spectrum Valuation Act would help us give more broadband access to more people.

1448384086863663105.text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS Mike Lee: Permitting for broadband infrastructure can gum up the process. My UNSHACKLE Act would help that permitting get done faster to build out the necessary skeleton of our broadband system.

1448383586525143040.text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS Mike Lee: Innovation requires access to broadband. It needs to be able to work its magic everywhere. Rural, urban, and everywhere in between.

1448383078531993604.text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS Mike Lee: Utah has been an early pioneer in becoming a regulatory sandbox. Innovators can see where we are going better than regulators. New ideas are all too often restricted by burdensome regulatory environments. Utah is leading the way in giving new ideas regulatory freedom.

1448382393413521409.text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS Mike Lee: The youth of our state are one of our biggest advantages. We have a young population, a lot of people moving in, and a lot of people getting involved in tech to do good in the world.

1448381630180102146.text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS Tim Cook: Four-year college is one path, but it’s only one. There are so many jobs that don’t require four-year degrees.

1448381130508587011.text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes Tim Cook : @Ancestry, @CanvasLMS , and many other Utah tech companies represent what tech is about -- helping humanity move forward.

1448380396211740687.text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes Mike Lee: “I always enjoy getting to introduce a friend to another group of friends. Nothing says entrepreneurship like @SiliconSlopes or @Tim_Cook. So I’m glad I could help bring these groups together.”

1448379398172852224.text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes Josh James: “When it comes to technology, Senator Lee has worked to protect innovation, American ingenuity and competition that our entrepreneurs value.”

Live highlights from my conversation with @Tim_Cook at @SiliconSlopes Summit 2021.

1354921215455096835.text: I look forward to improving antitrust enforcement this Congress. It is imperative that we ensure markets work for consumers, not just monopolists. 1354921214423273473.text: We need the enforcers to (finally) enforce the antitrust laws against those who harm competition and consumers, including Big Tech. But we need to do it in a way that doesn't allow judges to usurp Congress's legislative role. 4/5

1354921213303418884.text: Let's also note what the consumer welfare standard is NOT: it is not a narrow concern with price. As Judge Bork wrote, it encompasses “innovation, choice among differing products" and quality. That more than covers the ways in which markets like Big Tech are failing us. 3/5

1354921211785076737.text: What is the consumer welfare standard? It's a guardrail that ensures 1) the primary beneficiaries of the antitrust laws are the people, not big business; and 2) that unelected judges are not allowed to use antitrust to advance their own political preferences. 2/5

1354921210715525130.text: There’s a lot of talk about antitrust legislation this Congress. One thing lost in many proposed reforms: the consumer welfare standard is not a get-out-of-jail-free card for Big Tech. We don’t need to change the law, we need to enforce it. 1/5

1241749422926639111.text: If you’re on social media today and agree please get the word out on this and contact your Senators. It’s not too late. The bill isn’t finished. A big, bipartisan coalition can still win this. We can #GoBig4Charity. Who’s with me? (15/15)

1241749421890703362.text: This is not a partisan or ideological issue. It’s more like a blind spot we want everyone to see. Congress is understandably focused on business liquidity. We’re digging deep to rescue the economy. We have to do the same for our equally important civil society. (14/15)

1241749420758257664.text: That’s why a one-year, charitable deduction is essential to a comprehensive coronavirus relief package. Rs and Ds are ready to #GoBig4Charity. We just need the chance to show it. The base bill can still be changed, or we try to offer a bipartisan amendment on the floor. (13/15)

1241749419344695298.text: This morning, millions are attending virtual church services in their living rooms, praying that this crisis passes. And it will. And when it does, we’re going to need those churches, and all our service orgs, back on the front lines to rebuild and renew our communities. (12/15)

1241749418019360769.text: And based on conversations I’ve had the last few days with Republican and Democrat colleagues, I am morally certain that there is overwhelming bipartisan support for a huge-but-temporary, one-year policy fix for the charitable giving deduction. (11/15)

1241749416983347200.text: This year, we’re going to *want* all Americans – especially rich ones! – pouring their money into local charities. If there must be a cap, $300,000 or $30,000 makes *much* more sense than $300. (10/15)

1241749415594991626.text: The American people are ready to “go big” with their own personal contributions to the national relief effort. But Congress has to help them do it. In all honesty, for this one year, the deduction shouldn’t be capped at all. (9/15)

1241749414508662785.text: Non-profits are looking at shortfalls this year in the tens, maybe hundreds of billions of dollars. Ten percent of U.S. jobs are in the non-profit sector. These organizations don’t need a bailout – they need blow-out. Just this one time, this one year. (8/15)

1241749413015453696.text: This is crucial. Fixing the charitable deduction for 2020 may give our relief efforts the best policy bang for the buck. Unfortunately, the draft proposal would cap this special, one-time deduction at… $300 per person! That’s short by at least one zero. (7/15)

1241749411883073536.text: The good news is, negotiators of Phase 3 are aware of this need. The first draft includes a 1 time, 1 year fix that moves the charitable deduction “above the line” on 2020 tax forms. That would enable all tax filers to deduct charitable donations from their taxable income. (6/15)

1241749410788376582.text: Ivy League universities and the Smithsonian Institution may be fine. But small and medium-sized local non-profits – the lifeblood of American culture, cooperation, and community – are going to be hanging by a thread. Congress has to make them a priority. (5/15)

1241749409727160320.text: Think about what months of social distancing and shrunken family budgets will do to churches, charities, soup kitchens, homeless shelters, drug rehab centers, museums, elderly outreach, libraries, youth sports leagues, orchestras and theater companies? (4/15)

1241749408682778625.text: It’s not just the for-profit economy that is suffering and will suffer from the COVID outbreak. Civil society – all those millions of non-profits around the country – are getting hammered too. (3/15)

1241749407499980802.text: In D.C., the theme of the relief effort is to “go big.” Members on both sides want to overwhelm the fears and uncertainty now strangling our economy. But in this crisis, it’s not enough just for the *government* to “go big” – we have to empower *everyone* to go big, too. (2/15)

1037344204618391552.text: By 10:05 am — less than 30 minutes after the hearing began — I counted 18 acts of disruption.

1037056543798296578.text: Here’s a quick update on today’s #SCOTUS hearing so far: https://t.co/8rEnaUFsyr

1037009620504653824.text: There’s a better way for the #Senate to approach its work. This process should be about a jurist’s qualifications, character, and approach to judging. It should not be about results in a select number of cases.

1037009452027858944.text: This undermines the legitimacy of the courts. Over time, no free people would accept a judiciary that simply imposes its own preferences on the country, absent fidelity to legal principle.

1037009378312896512.text: Every current member of the Supreme Court has adhered to a similar principle.

1037009328702668800.text: Sure enough, last term in Ortiz v. United States, #SCOTUS considered a case implicating the scope of Marbury. Likewise, Justice Ginsburg created the so-called “Ginsburg standard”—no previews, forecasts, or hints.

1037009258360004608.text: Nominees, for the most part, have resisted trading confirmation in exchange for promises on how they’ll vote. To give two famous examples: Justice Scalia refused to say whether Marbury v. Madison was settled law, on the ground that it could come before him.

1037009177762246656.text: This history shows that, over the better part of a century, the Judiciary Committee has gradually created a norm in which members demand that nominees talk about specific cases in return for favorable treatment.

1037009087836372992.text: Without getting into the gory details, suffice to say that Senator Ted Kennedy and Judge Bork did not agree on constitutional law. Kennedy’s response was to savage – unfairly – the results he thought Bork would reach.

1037009022489124864.text: Twenty-eight years later, the Senate considered Robert Bork’s nomination. This was another turning point, and in my view, remains a rock-bottom moment for the Senate.

1037008855488704514.text: Justice Stewart’s 1959 nomination was another turning point. Senators seeking to resist Brown v. Board of Education wanted to grill Stewart about his views on integration. Others wanted to grill Stewart about his views on national security.

1037008720545361920.text: But Senators also worried that Frankfurter was a radical based on his defense of anarchists in court. So again, Senators wanted assurances Frankfurter would reach certain results. Frankfurter, however, declined to engage w/Senators & insisted his public record spoke for itself

1037008646226567169.text: The next important moment was in 1939, when Justice Frankfurter became the first #SCOTUS nominee to testify before the Senate. At the time, Frankfurter was controversial in part because he was he was born overseas.

1037008522624548867.text: They didn’t ask Brandeis to testify, but asked outside witnesses to talk about his nomination.

1037008470644535297.text: But Senators also wanted to determine whether Brandeis would use a seat on #SCOTUS to advocate for progressive causes he championed as a public-interest attorney. They wanted to know how he would vote in particular cases.

1037008426809913345.text: The first #SCOTUS confirmation hearing occurred in 1916, when Justice Brandeis was nominated. Brandeis was controversial for several reasons—including, it has to be said, because he was Jewish.

1037008361781428224.text: When you look at the history, that is precisely why confirmation hearings developed—so that Senators could ask nominees how they would vote in particular cases.

1037008100585349121.text: Some of these unfair questions will ask him to promise to vote a certain way in particular cases likely to come before the Court.

1037008049733623808.text: Over the next few days, senators will ask Judge #Kavanaugh questions about #SCOTUS cases, his record, and his qualifications. Some of these questions will be fair. Many others will be unfair.

1012786019177988097.text: The second bill I plan to introduce is a new Homestead Act – one to help ordinary Americans in the 21st century. #utpol #SIPublicLands

1012785909119508480.text: Specifically, my bill would prohibit the president from designating or expanding a national monument in the state unless both Congress and the state legislature pass resolutions approving the designation. #utpol #SIPublicLands

1012785837938003968.text: The first, the Protecting Utah’s Rural Communities Act, would protect Utah from future Antiquities Act abuses by giving Utah the same protections currently enjoyed by Wyoming and Alaska. #utpol #SIPublicLands

1012784598911275008.text: Our immediate task is to rein in that government and reclaim a space for ordinary Americans to live in freedom. I am working on three specific bills to do just that. #utpol #SIPublicLands

1012784270081970177.text: Rural Americans want what all Americans want: a dignified, decent-paying job. A family to love and support. A healthy community whose future is determined by local residents—not by their self-styled betters thousands of miles away. #utpol #SIPublicLands

1012784076363837440.text: Locals aren’t as lucky. While tourism has contributed much to the West, communities can’t survive on it alone. It is a complement to – not a substitute – for broader economic development. #utpol #SIPublicLands

1012783608300494848.text: They delight in seeing vast swathes of untouched lands, fulfilling their idyllic notions of the West where they can jet in, spend a few days at the cabin, take pictures of animals, and then retreat to their enclaves on the coasts. #utpol #SIPublicLands

1012783347876159488.text: Things have only gotten worse since. An even more extreme environmental movement, an alliance of privilege between celebrities, activists, and corporate elites now want to save the Earth at the expense of our rural communities. #utpol #SIPublicLands

1012783003129581569.text: No longer would it be the official policy of the United States government to sell back the land and entrust it to the people. Instead, the policy would be to keep the land for itself.  #utpol #SIPublicLands

1012782911882518528.text: And in 1976, Congress formalized federal control over federal lands by passing the Federal Land Policy and Management Act. This repealed the Homestead Acts and completely upended federal government’s public land policy. #utpol #SIPublicLands

1012782838595358720.text: The amount of grazing on federal land went into steep decline, causing an exodus from the range that was never reversed. #utpol #SIPublicLands

1012782784165896192.text: Between the mid-1960s and 1980, the amount of wilderness rose from 11.5 million acres to 82.7 million acres—an increase of 716% in less than two decades. #utpol #SIPublicLands

1012782729430102016.text: The activists used land-use restrictions as an “all-purpose tool for stopping economic activity,” in the words of political scientist R. McGreggor Cawley. #utpol #SIPublicLands

1012782652645171201.text: But in the 60s and 70s environmental activists began exploiting public fears about overpopulation and pollution. #utpol #SIPublicLands

1012781934215352320.text: The first westerners were optimistic about federal control of western lands. Teddy Roosevelt and Gifford Pinchot advocated for active management of the land, in cooperation with local interests. #utpol #SIPublicLands

1012781727788433408.text: Fifty, sixty, even seventy percent of the land within Western states’ boundaries was – and remains – controlled by Washington. #utpol #SIPublicLands

1012781236476170240.text: While they were ultimately successful in petitioning Congress to transfer their public lands from federal to state management, Western states have not been so lucky. #utpol #SIPublicLands

1012780750922493953.text: Take Illinois and Missouri, for example. At one point, the federal government controlled more than 90% of their land. #utpol #SIPublicLands

1012780576661700609.text: The promise to sell federal lands in Utah is right there, enshrined in federal law. But, unlike states farther East, the commitment to us was never honored. #utpol #SIPublicLands

1012780367428898816.text: When Utah came into the Union in 1896, Section 9 of its statehood enabling legislation declared that public land located within the state “shall be sold by the United States subsequent to the admission of said state into the union.” #utpol #SIPublicLands

1012780296218054656.text: While Easterners and Midwesterners had almost-total control of the land within their boundaries, Western states like Utah entered the Union on inferior terms – as tenants to negligent landlords. #utpol #SIPublicLands

1012780223081959424.text: But by the time Utah and other states entered the Union, Congress had turned its attention elsewhere. Manifest destiny left us behind. #utpol #SIPublicLands

1012779830042157062.text: The Homestead Acts were an engine for middle-class opportunity and growth and set the American standard for the disposition of public resources. #utpol #SIPublicLands

1012779662542503936.text: The cornerstone of this policy was the Homestead Acts which transferred 270 million acres of land out of federal control and into the hands of ordinary Americans. #utpol #SIPublicLands

1012779111180394501.text: Throughout the 19th century, Lawmakers sought to facilitate expansion of the nation by acquiring land—and then transferring it to the people, so they could live out their lives as responsible citizens of the republic. #utpol #SIPublicLands

1012776756913287168.text: How did it come to pass that nearly half of the land in the West is owned by the federal government, compared to just 5 percent of the land in the East? #utpol #SIPublicLands

1012774012303368193.text: WATCH LIVE: Major speech on public lands policy at @SutherlandInst: “Federal Lands and Royal Forests." https://t.co/FlYSAwyzeS #utpol #SIPublicLands

1007491076779700224.text: What’s the best argument you can think of for NOT letting the Senate vote on the Due Process Guarantee Act?

1007429974679171075.text: The DPGA corrects the mistake Congress made in 2012 and protects Americans from indefinite government detention. https://t.co/RXgpkFeKUK.…

1007424609195524096.text: What kind of country would we have if we freely allowed our government to detain us indefinitely without charge, trial, or counsel?

1007421131039674368.text: Please tell your senators to support the Due Process Guarantee Act as an amendment to the National Defense Authorization Act.  Let’s vote!

1007420467421110273.text: @sebastian_byron @conncarroll I’m just trying to fix a problem in the law—one that is easy to ignore today, but could give rise to significant problems.

1007420137618763776.text: @sebastian_byron Making law is my job.  We are one step way from fixing a bad law and making a better one.

1007419734369931264.text: By contrast, imagine the immense harm that could come from a law that authorizes the indefinite detention of American citizens!

1007419372909006854.text: Where is the harm in a law saying that Americans can’t be indefinitely detained without charge or trial on US soil?

1007418990120095744.text: Our govt isn’t now indefinitely detaining US citizens without charge or trial. But why leave a law in place that purports to authorize that?

1007416770016182272.text: Why would anyone who voted for a nearly identical version of the DPGA in 2012 now deny his colleagues the right to cast this vote?

1007416118913437696.text: Why block such a vote, especially when 68 senators wanted to take that vote?

1007415885781524480.text: Why would a senator object to letting the Senate even VOTE on whether to protect Americans’ due process rights?

1007415360021295104.text: Why would anyone choose to vote against a bill restoring existing constitutional protections that have been undermined by a bad law?

1007414657592778757.text: Had we voted on the DPGA, it would have passed, protecting the due process rights of hundreds of millions of American citizens.

1007414306982461446.text: The DPGA should have received a vote in the Senate.  A total of 68 senators voted against a motion to table the DPGA; they wanted a vote!

1007413757390225408.text: The DPGA, which I authored along with @SenFeinstein, was pending as an amendment to this year’s National Defense Authorization Act.

1007413016130924547.text: American citizens arrested on American soil should never be subject to indefinite detention without charge, trial, jury, or counsel.

1007412771456212992.text: @UnsolicitedOpin Sadly, members of both political parties passed and later protected section 1021 of the 2012 NDAA, which made DPGA necessary.

1007411510057099264.text: The American people cannot be asked to wait another moment before their due process rights are protected by the Due Process Guarantee Act.

1007411098067357696.text: Each year, @SenFeinstein and I have been told we’d get a vote on the DPGA “at some point,” but it has not happened.  The time has come!

1007410696232022016.text: Ever since 2012, @SenFeinstein and I have been trying to put the DPGA back into each year’s National Defense Authorization Act.

1007410262188740608.text: @SenFeinstein and I introduced the DPGA in 2012. It passed with 67 votes, but was somehow removed from the NDAA before final passage.

1007407990251622401.text: The DPGA was made necessary by Sec. 1021 of the 2012 NDAA, which purported to give the government unrestrained power to detain Americans.

1007406485763166211.text: The Due Process Guarantee Act would protect U.S. citizens on U.S. soil from being detained indefinitely without charge, counsel, or trial.

1007404780573032448.text: American citizens arrested on American soil should never be subject to indefinite detention without charge, trial, jury, or counsel.

976237822381318145.text: The power to declare war belongs to Congress. By tabling this measure today, we have chosen yet again to abdicate our constitutional responsibility.

976163926168784896.text: This is a fast track process, this is really why the war power resolution matters here. It helps the Senate exercise it’s Article I Section 8 war power. 6/6

976163875694444545.text: The war powers resolution provides us with the internal procedural mechanism for putting this up for a vote. This is a privileged motion, meaning we can get it brought to the floor and doesn’t require what we call cloture. 5/6

976163825102794752.text: That doesn’t mean it (the War Power Resolution) is unconstitutional. It’s not. This is exactly what the Constitution contemplates. 4/6

976163760296644609.text: Now, that’s not surprising because the whole purpose of the War Powers Resolution was to allow Congress to exercise its power to declare war, so presidents are naturally going to resist efforts to restrict and restrain their power. 3/6

694995826326769664.text: Senate doesn't need to eliminate filibuster. Better solution is to work more than 3 days per week. Allow time for debate and deliberation.

694994766069698563.text: The real problem in the Senate isn't the filibuster. What we really need is for Senate to be the Senate: an open, deliberative body.

694993902651236352.text: What a healthy Senate lacks in efficiency, it makes up for with open, robust deliberation.

694993308288970752.text: The filibuster is about leverage, and that leverage is essential to maintaining equality and engendering deliberation among Senators.

694992993183465473.text: Everything in the Senate is rooted in occupational equality of all Senators - filibuster protects this.

694992340147118081.text: The Senate is broken, but the filibuster has almost nothing to do with it.
